questions.text:
Match the various forms of dermographism with their correct descriptions.
1. Black dermographism a. Due to capillary vasoconstriction
following light stroking of the skin
2. Simple dermographism b. Erythematous line studded with punctate weals
3. White dermographism c. Skin discolouration after pressure from a metallic object.
4. Cholinergic dermographism d. Triple response of erythema, oedema, and a surrounding flare
questions.solution:
The correct answer is 1-c, 2-d, 3-a, 4-b.

Dermographism refers to an exaggerated flare and weal response that occurs when skin is stroked or scratched. Dermographism is the most common form of chronic inducible urticaria or physical urticaria.

Various forms of dermographism include:

Black discoloration of the skin after pressure from a metallic object
White capillary vasoconstriction follows light stroking or pressure on the skin and occurs normally but is particularly pronounced in atopic eczema
Simple triple response of local erythema due to capillary vasodilatation, followed by edema and a surrounding flare due to axon reflex‐induced dilatation of arterioles after stroking the skin.
Cholinergic demographic response consists of an erythematous line studded with punctate weals, seen in some patients with cholinergic urticaria

The image below shows cholinergic urticaria.

The image below shows white demographism.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man presents with a painful skin lesion as shown below. There was no history of any recent trauma. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient in the given scenario has a painful, well-demarcated raised erythematous lesion involving the skin over the ear. The most probable diagnosis is erysipelas.

Erysipelas is a skin infection caused by group A beta-hemolytic streptococcus, Streptococcus pyogenes that involves the upper dermis and superficial lymphatics. It presents as erythematous, painful, indurated, and inflamed skin lesions.

Facial erythema spreading to the pinna is known as Milian's ear sign. This sign is used to distinguish between erysipelas and cellulitis of the facial region. In erysipelas, this sign is positive since there will be involvement of the ear while it is not seen in cellulitis. The pinna region is usually spared in cellulitis, as there is no deeper dermal tissue and subcutaneous fat in the pinna. Thus the pinna involvement supports the diagnosis of erysipelas rather than cellulitis. It can also be distinguished from cellulitis by its well-demarcated borders. (Option A)

Other options:

Option C: Perichondritis is an infection of the skin and tissues around the cartilage of the pinna. Common causes include trauma due to either iatrogenic (surgical incision) or non-iatrogenic (laceration, hematoma) origin. It can also be due to the extension of infection from diffuse otitis externa or furuncle of the meatus. Pseudomonas aeruginosa is an organism commonly implicated. Initially, the pinna is red, hot, painful, and stiff. In the later stages, an abscess may form between the cartilage and perichondrium with necrosis of cartilage as the cartilage survives only on the blood supply from its perichondrium. Since there was no history of trauma, perichondritis is not the most probable cause for this given scenario.

Option D: Parotid abscess is the suppuration of the parotid space most commonly caused by Staphylococcus aureus. It is seen in the postoperative period, dehydration, and debilitated patients. Patients appear toxic with swelling, redness, induration, and tenderness in the parotid gland and at the angle of the mandible.

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient presents to you with gait abnormalities and tremors. An eye examination reveals Kayser–Fleischer ring. His serum ceruloplasmin levels are low, and his urinary copper levels are high. Which of the following signs is likely to be associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical findings of gait abnormality and tremor with the Kayser–Fleischer (KF) ring and low serum ceruloplasmin with high urinary copper levels are suggestive of Wilson’s disease. Blue lunulae are associated with this condition.

Wilson's disease is an autosomal recessive disease with a deficiency of a copper‐transporting ATPase, leading to reduced excretion of copper. Copper accumulates in the liver, brain, cornea, kidney, and other tissues. Dermatological manifestations are mild and as follows:

  • Blue lunulae (Azure lunulae) of the nails
  • Xeroderma and grey‐brown hyperpigmentation on the extensor surfaces of the legs
  • Pruritus and spider naevi due to liver disease

Hepatic manifestations of Wilson's disease include hepatitis, cirrhosis, or liver failure and usually occur in childhood and adolescence. Neurological manifestations include dysarthria, tremors, dystonia, and drooling. Some patients present with behavioral changes or psychosis. A greenish-brown KF ring may be seen at the limbus of the cornea.

Serum ceruloplasmin concentrations are low, with raised 24-hour urine copper excretion.

Treatment is with chelators like penicillamine and trientine, which increase the excretion of copper. Liver transplantation is indicated if there is liver failure.

A KF ring is shown in the image below.

Blue lunulae (Azure lunulae) of the nails is also caused due to argyria, hemoglobin-M disease, hereditary acro-labial telangiectasias, and chemotherapeutic agents such as zidovudine, phenolphthalein, and hydroxyurea.

Other options:

Option A: Trachyonychia presents as a rough surface affecting the nail plate. The nails may become opalescent fragile, with fine longitudinal ridges. When it involves all 20 nails, it is called twenty-nail dystrophy. It is associated with alopecia areata, psoriasis, and lichen planus.

Option B: Dorsal nail pterygium refers to the winged appearance of a central fibrotic band proximally dividing the nail in two. The fibrotic band then obstructs normal nail growth. It is associated with trauma, lichen planus, idiopathic atrophy of the nail, leprosy, and graft‐versus‐host disease. 

Option C: Red lunulae refers to erythema of all or part of the lunula and may affect all digits but is most prominent in the thumb. It is associated with cardiac failure and subungual tumors like myxoid cysts or glomus tumors (single-digit red lunula). Dotted red lunulae are seen in psoriasis and alopecia areata.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions does not reveal apple jelly sign on performing the following test?
questions.solution:
The image shown above demonstrates a diascopy. All the options mentioned above reveal apple jelly sign on diascopy except nevus anemicus.

Diascopy is a bedside maneuver performed to assess superficial erythema in dermatological conditions.

It involves pressing a glass slide or a stiff, clear, colorless piece of plastic onto the skin to compress blood out of small vessels, to allow evaluation of other colors. Vessels can be seen to blanch and fill, by varying the amount of pressure on the skin, which is different for different conditions.

The purpose of this procedure is to empty blood from the superficial vessels to determine if skin redness is due to blood present within the vessels or extravasated onto the skin.

Diascopy is of particular value in the following conditions:

  • Granulomatous conditions: A translucent brownish color is seen on the diascopy, known as apple jelly nodules (apple jelly sign). They are seen in sarcoidosis, granuloma annulare, and lupus vulgaris.
  • To distinguish nevus anemicus from nevus depigmentosus: On diascopy, nevus anemicus (congenital white patch of vasoconstriction) becomes indistinguishable with the merging of the lesion into the surrounding skin. However, the border of nevus depigmentosus remains unaltered after diascopy.
  • Spider nevi - The application of medium pressure to a spider nevus can compress radiating arterioles and allow visualization of pulsatile flow in the feeding vessel.
  • Differentiation of erythema (vasodilation) - disappears and purpura (extravasated blood) - remains unaltered on diascopy.

questions.text: While examining a patient with pemphigus vulgaris, you notice that applying pressure from the side of the bulla causes it to extend to the adjacent unblistered skin. What is this sign known as?
questions.solution:
The extension of a blister to adjacent unblistered skin when pressure is applied from the side of the bulla is known as the Lutz sign or traditional bulla spread sign.

Other options:

Option B: Nikolsky's sign refers to the easy peeling of the skin by applying tangential pressure over a bony prominence. It is classically seen in pemphigus vulgaris, pemphigus foliaceus, and staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome.

Option C: Dimple sign refers to the dimpled appearance of a dermatofibroma on squeezing the adjacent skin.

Option D: The Asboe-Hansen sign, a variation of the bulla spread sign, involves applying pressure to the bulla over the top, which causes the spread of the bulla to adjacent unblistered skin.

questions.text: A child is brought to the dermatology outpatient department with the following skin findings. On complete physical examination, no other abnormalities were found. Hearing was normal. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above image showing a V-shaped congenital hypomelanotic patch in the absence of any other pathological clinical signs suggests a diagnosis of piebaldism.

Piebaldism is a congenital disorder caused by a dominant mutation in the KIT gene, leading to impaired migration of melanocytes. Clinically, it presents an isolated hypopigmented patch at birth. The biopsy specimen from the lesion shows absent melanocytes or large atypical melanocytes.

It affects the population and affects both sexes equally. The most common clinical presentation is the presence of a V-shaped hypomelanotic patch on the forehead at birth.

Diagnosis is mainly clinical. Treatment is conservative and includes sun protection at the site of the hypomelanotic patch. Epidermal or skin grafting can be tried for aesthetic purposes of treatment.

Piebaldism can be distinguished from vitiligo because of the neonatal presence of white patches.

Option B: Skin findings suggestive of piebaldism, along with the presence of sensorineural deafness, point toward Waardenburg syndrome.

Option C: Oculocutaneous albinism (OCA) is a rare autosomal recessive disorder. It is characterized by generalized depigmentation of the skin, hair, and eye due to a deficiency in melanin biosynthesis.

Option D: Chédiak–Higashi syndrome is a rare autosomal recessive disorder. It is characterized by hypopigmentation of the skin and eye (fair skin, translucent iris), immunodeficiency, and possibly neurological symptoms. It is suspected in patients with features of oculocutaneous albinism combined with severe pyogenic infections.

questions.text: You are examining the nails of a patient with psoriasis. Which among the following nail findings is pathognomonic of this condition?
questions.solution:
Image 3 shows the oil drop sign/ salmon patches, which is a specific pathognomonic sign seen in psoriasis.

Psoriasis is a chronic inflammatory condition of the skin, characterized by red, scaly, sharply demarcated, indurated plaques usually seen on the extensor surfaces and scalp. It can affect any part of the nail unit, including the nail bed, nail matrix, and hyponychium. Nail changes in psoriasis are seen commonly. Various nail dystrophies that are seen in psoriasis-

  • Nail matrix disease presents as pits (most common), ridges, and grooves of the nail plate. 
  • Nail bed disease presents as subungual oil drops, subungual hyperkeratosis, splinter haemorrhages, and distal onycholysis.

Related Pearl: Nail changes in psoriasis

Nail changes in psoriasis are present in about 40% of the cases at any point in time. Nail psoriasis is associated with more extensive psoriasis, longer disease duration, family history of psoriasis, and the presence of psoriatic arthritis.

Subungal oil drop sign or Salmon Patch is a highly specific pathognomonic sign seen in Nail psoriasis. It is a yellow-red discoloration in the nail bed resembling a drop of oil.

Nail pitting however is the most frequent sign. Individual pits are uniformly sized, deep and irregular in nature. These nail pits are also known as Thimble pits and are due to the involvement of the proximal nail matrix.

Nail Bed disease also causes subungual hyperkeratosis, splinter hemorrhages, and distal onycholysis.

Leuconychia may also be present.

Trachonychia or Twenty Nail dystrophy may be present in severe cases.

Image :  Pitting is the commonest manifestation of nail psoriasis.

Image: oil drops visible in the nail bed.

Image: pitting and salmon patches in fingernails.

Image: Leukonychia in a patient with psoriasis.

 

Features of Nail Psoriasis – Mnemonic

“Nail – POLISH”

  • P – Pitting
  • O – Oil drop sign, Onycholysis
  • L – Leuconychia
  • I – Irregular pitting pattern
  • S – Splinter Hemorrhage
  • H – Hyperkeratosis (Subungual)

questions.text: Groove sign of Greenblatt is seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
The groove sign of Greenblatt is seen in cases of lymphogranuloma venerum (LGV). 

It is a pathognomonic sign of LGV in which a groove-like depression is seen between femoral and inguinal lymph nodes above and below the inguinal ligament.

LGV is a sexually transmitted disease caused by serovars L1-L3 of Chlamydia trachomatis

Patients present with genital ulcers, inguinal swelling or rectal discharge, and bleeding. The disease occurs in 3 stages. The primary stage is characterized by the appearance of a single, non‐indurated, shallow genital ulcer. This heals rapidly and leaves no scar. In the secondary stage of LGV, along with the groove sign, unilateral lymphadenopathy and painful enlargement of glands in the form of buboes are seen. The tertiary stage occurs in chronic untreated lesions and consists of genital edema, polypoid growths, fistulae, ulceration and scarring.

The detection of serovar L of Chlamydia trachomatis from the site of infection confirms the diagnosis. This is done by nucleic acid amplification tests (NAATs) and confirmed by real‐time polymerase chain reaction (PCR) assays for LGV‐specific DNA. In earlier times, the Frei test, which showed a positive cutaneous hypersensitivity reaction to purified chlamydial antigen was done but is now obsolete.

Treatment:

First-line treatment employs the administration of oral doxycycline 100 mg given twice daily for 21 days and the patient should be thoroughly investigated to exclude other STIs.

Fluctuant buboes may require aspiration but the surgical incision is usually contraindicated. Recent sexual partners of the patient should also be notified.

The image below shows the groove sign.

Other options:

Option B: Syphilis is primarily a sexually transmitted disease caused by Treponema palladium but vertical transmission is also possible. It commonly presents as a hard, painless genital ulcer with induration, followed by the development of rubbery enlargement of inguinal lymph nodes.

Option C: Gonorrhoea is primarily a sexually transmitted bacterial infection caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae but vertical transmission during childbirth can occur. In men, it often presents as acute urethritis accompanied by a profuse urethral puru­lent discharge. Most women with early gonorrhea are asymptomatic. The primary site of infection in women is the cervix.

Option D: Herpes genitalis is an infection of the genital skin or mucosa with herpes simplex virus HSV 1 and HSV 2. It presents as painful genital ulcers and dysuria. It is usually preceded by a prodrome of general malaise.

The following image shows genital ulcers seen in herpes genitalis.

Related Pearl: Sexually transmitted infections

Genital herpes- caused by herpes simplex virus (human herpesvirus 1 and 2).

  • It appears as blisters (usually multiple) that lead to ulcer formation on breaking.
  • The ulcers are painful.

 

Granuloma inguinale / Donovanosis- caused by Klebsiella granulomatis (formerly known as Calymmatobacterium granulomatis).

  • It usually causes beefy red genital ulcers that may bleed on touch.
  • The ulcers are usually painless.
  • Lymphadenopathy is usually absent but subcutaneous granulomas cause pseudo buboes. 
  • Microscopy shows Donovan bodies with closed safety pin appearance

The given images show genital ulcer in granuloma inguinale:

 

Chancroid/ Soft chancre- caused by Haemophilus ducreyi.

  • Causes genital ulcers that are non indurated with undermined edges.
  • The ulcer is painful.
  • Multiple/ Kissing ulcers develop due to autoinoculation from the primary ulcer.
  • It usually causes tender unilateral inguinal buboes. 
  • Microscopy- School of fish/Railroad track appearance

 

Syphilitic chancre/ Hard chancre- caused by Treponema pallidum.

  • It presents as a small, button-like, indurated ulcer that is usually round/oval.
  • The ulcer is painless.
  • Causes painless lymphadenopathy.
  • Microscopy- Spirochetes seen on dark ground illumination.

 

Lymphogranuloma venereum- caused by Chlamydia trachomatis.

  • It usually presents with a transient single shallow ulcer that heals rapidly and usually goes unnoticed.
  • The secondary stage presents with tender inguinal buboes.
  • Groove sign is seen when the lymph nodes above and below the inguinal ligament are enlarged leading to the appearance of a groove.

The given images show the ulcer and the groove sign seen in LGV:

 

Gonorrhea- caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae.

  • It leads to purulent inflammation of the genital mucous membranes.
  • It may present as urethritis, cervicitis, epididymo‐orchitis, or pelvic inflammatory disease.
  • The usual presentation is acute urethritis with complaints of burning dysuria and purulent discharge.

The given image shows purulent genital inflammation due to gonorrhea:

Related Pearl: Syndromic Management of Sexually Transmitted Infections

Partner Management when asymptomatic is not required for Gardenella vaginalis, Candida and Herpes infections.

questions.text: A 10-year-old male patient presented with macular lesions on the trunk, as shown in the image, which are associated with flushing, and pruritus. On stroking the macular lesion with a blunt object, there is erythema around the reddish-brown macules. What is this known as?
questions.solution:
Macular lesions as shown in the image associated with flushing, pruritus, and erythema around the reddish-brown macules on stoking the lesion are known as Darier’s sign and are seen in cutaneous mastocytosis.

Cutaneous mastocytosis is an acquired condition where there is a massive increase in the number of mast cells in the skin and other tissues. Urticaria pigmentosa is the most common among these conditions and is characterized by numerous reddish‐brown or pale monomorphic maculopapules, plaques, or nodules. It is associated with flushing, pruritus, redness, and swelling caused by the release of histamine, leukotrienes, and prostaglandins from skin mast cells. They are in symmetrical distribution and can occur anywhere on the body except the palms and soles and are seen maximum on the trunk and thighs. The lesions are positive for Darier's sign.

Darier's sign is the development of urticarial halo and erythema around the reddish-brown macules after mild trauma, including scratching or rubbing of the lesion. It is caused by the release of histamine due to degranulation of the mast cells. However, Darier's sign is not highly specific to mastocytosis as it is also rarely seen in juvenile xanthogranuloma and acute lymphoblastic leukemia of neonates.

The image shows Darier's sign on the left shoulder.

 

Other options:

Option B:  Pseudo-Darier’s sign is seen in congenital smooth muscle hamartoma, and piloerection of the muscle is responsible for the sign.

Option C: Facial eczema sparing the periorbital, perinasal, and perioral areas is known as the headlight sign and is a feature of atopic dermatitis.

Option D: Hertoghe's sign or Queen Anne's sign is defined as loss of lateral one-third of eyebrows (superciliary madarosis). It is seen in various conditions, such as:

  • Hypothyroidism
  • Lepromatous leprosy
  • Atopic dermatitis
  • Trichotillomania
  • Alopecia areata.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy presented with complaints of multiple skin lesions over his back. On examination, various erythematous, scaly lesions parallel to the ribs are noted, as shown in the image given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario, with the image showing the Christmas tree sign, is suggestive of pityriasis rosea.

Pityriasis rosea/pityriasis circinata et maculata of Vidal is an acute self-limiting papulosquamous disorder. It is commonly seen in children and young adults.

Even though the exact cause is unknown, T-cell-mediated immunity and infectious etiology are thought to be responsible for this condition. An association with infectious agents like human herpesvirus-6 (HHV-6) and human herpesvirus-7 (HHV-7) has been found recently.

Clinical features include:

  • Prodrome of a sore throat, gastrointestinal disturbance, fever, or arthralgia.
  • Herald patch - Large and conspicuous eruptions on the thigh, upper arm, trunk, or neck covered by fine scales

The image given below shows a herald patch.

  • After 5-15 days, it turns into discrete oval lesions, dull pink in color and covered by fine dry silvery-grey scales. 
  • These secondary lesions occur as macules and papules that are elliptical or ovular, symmetric, and commonly involve the thorax, back, and abdomen.
  • It is followed by a marginal collarette of scale with central wrinkling and atrophy. The collarettes of the scales are attached peripherally. It is also called a hanging curtain sign.

The image given below shows collarette scales.

  • The long axes of the lesions characteristically follow the lines of skin tension parallel to the ribs in a Christmas tree pattern on the upper chest and back.

 The images given below show a Christmas tree pattern along the lines of skin tension on the back and the chest.

The rashes of pityriasis rosea usually resolve in 8 weeks.

Dermatoscopy shows:

  • Yellowish background-color
  • Peripheral arrangement of the scales
  • Patchy distribution of loosely arranged dotted vessels

Histopathology shows:

  • Superficial perivascular dermatitis with focal parakeratosis, hyperplasia and spongiosis in the epidermis.
  • Extravasated red blood cells, along with a perivascular infiltrate and subcorneal pustules, are seen in the dermis.

No treatment is required for asymptomatic cases. Application of irritants to the skin and tanning should be avoided since it may result in pigmentary changes. Emollients and antihistaminics are useful in relieving itching. If symptomatic, various agents are used like:

  • First-line agents: If severe pruritus or poor cosmetic appeal is present
    • Topical steroids
    • Narrowband UV-B therapy
  • Second-line agents: For a rapid resolution of the lesions, given the probable infectious etiology.
    • Antivirals like acyclovir
    • Macrolides like erythromycin

Pityriasis rosea within the first few weeks of gestation may cause premature delivery and fetal demise. Pityriasis rosea-like eruptions were reported after ingestion of drugs like gold, captopril, aspirin, metronidazole and clonidine and after vaccinations like BCG, influenza, diphtheria, hepatitis B, and Pneumococcus.

Other options:

Option A: Lichen planus has violaceous polygonal pruritic papules. It also has Wickham's striae.

Option C: Psoriasis has silvery-white plaques.

Option D: Pityriasis rubra pilaris has circumscribed follicular keratoses.

questions.text: A 36-year-old male presented to the OPD with purplish, itchy, flat-topped bumps on his shins along with a fine reticular lacy pattern on the oral mucosa as shown in the below image. Which of the following nail changes is most specific in this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical features of purplish, itchy, flat-topped lesions on shins and white streaks forming a lacework in the buccal mucosa, Wickham's striae, shown in the image are diagnostic of Lichen planus. Among all the nail changes seen in Lichen planus, Dorsal nail pterygium is the most specific nail finding.

The most common presentation of lichen planus is a well-defined area of purple-colored, itchy, flat-topped papules with interspersed lacy white lines known as Wickham's striae. This description is known as the characteristic "6 Ps" of lichen planus: planar (flat-topped), purple, polygonal, pruritic, papules, and plaques.

The main treatment in the case of persistent lichen planus is steroids. The first line of therapy is always topical steroids. The second-line treatment is with systemic steroids, retinoids, and PUVA.

Other options:

Option B: Subungal oil drop sign or Salmon patch is a pathognomonic sign seen in Nail psoriasis. 

Option C and D: Pup tent sign and thinning of the nail plate are the nail findings seen in lichen planus.

Related Pearl: Nail changes in lichen planus

Nail involvement in lichen planus occurs in up to 10% of the cases but is usually a minor feature of the disease.

Dorsal Nail Pterygium is the most specific nail change in Lichen planus. The fusion of dorsal nail fold and nail bed leads to pterygium.

The most frequent nail change is the exaggeration of longitudinal lines and linear depressions due to a slight thinning of the nail plate.

Pup-tent sign - elevation of nail in shape of tent

Trachyonychia - 20 nail dystrophy

Subungual Hyperkeratosis and Onycholysis

Longitudinal Melanonychia in Lichen Planus of the nail bed

Permanent destruction of several toenails with ulceration of soles (rare variant)

Nail pitting however is the most frequent sign. Individual pits are uniformly sized, deep and irregular in nature. These nail pits are also known as Thimble pits and are due to the involvement of the proximal nail matrix.

Nail Bed disease also causes subungual hyperkeratosis, splinter hemorrhages, and distal onycholysis.

  • I – Irregular pitting pattern
  • S – Splinter Hemorrhage
  • H – Hyperkeratosis (Subungual)

questions.text: What is the name of the finding in the image of a patient with dermatomyositis?
questions.solution:
The name of the finding in the image of a patient with dermatomyositis is the V sign. 

Dermatomyositis is characterized by symmetrical involvement of the muscles, commonly affecting the proximal muscles more than the distal muscles. Multiple dermatological manifestations also accompany it:

  • Shawl sign (Option B)- rashes in a sun-exposed area. This is present on the back of the neck and shoulders. 
  • V sign - rashes that occur in sun-exposed areas. They are present on the anterior neck and chest 
  • Heliotrope rash (Option D) is erythema and discolouration of the eyelids with periorbital oedema.
  • Gottron's sign (Option A) is an erythematous rash on the elbows, knees, ankles, and knuckles on the extensor surfaces.
  • Gottron's papules are raised with erythematous rashes over the knuckles. 
  • Edema of face and limbs
  • Flagellate erythema
  • Vasculopathic ulcers
  • Mechanic's hands in antisynthetase syndrome
  • Poikiloderma
  • Cutaneous calcinosis

Other manifestations of dermatomyositis include dysphagia, interstitial lung disease, bronchopneumonia, alveolitis, and myocarditis. 

Laboratory evaluation of patients with dermatomyositis will reveal elevated serum creatinine kinase and antinuclear antibodies. Electromyography will reveal features of myopathy. Histology will show perifascicular atrophy, and immunohistochemical staining will reveal myxovirus resistance protein A, a sensitive and specific marker. 

Treatment of dermatomyositis is immunotherapy with high-dose glucocorticoids as the first line. Methotrexate can be started as the second line if the patient presents with severe weakness, other organ system involvement, or those with a risk of steroid complications like patients with diabetes, osteoporosis, or postmenopausal women. Otherwise, second-line agents are only started in patients who do not show improvement after 2-4 months of treatment with prednisone or those who cannot be maintained on a low dose. Triple therapy with intravenous immunoglobulin or rituximab may be required.

questions.text: For a patient with a suspected inherited connective tissue disorder, identify the sign demonstrated below.
questions.solution:
The picture depicts Gorlin’s sign, which is the ability of patients with Ehlers-Danlos syndrome (EDS) to touch the tip of the nose with the tip of their tongue.

EDS is a connective tissue disorder occurring due to genetic defects involved in collagen synthesis and action. It is characterized by hyperextensibility of skin, hypermobile joints, easy bruising, and poor wound healing.

Other options:

Option A: Hertoghe’s sign is defined as the loss of lateral one-third of the eye-brows (superciliary madarosis) seen in leprosy, myxedema, atopic dermatitis, trichotillomania, ectodermal dysplasia, discoid lupus erythematosus, alopecia areata, syphilis, systemic sclerosis, HIV infection, and hypothyroidism.

Option B: Higoumenaki's sign refers to enlargement of the sternal end of the clavicle, frequently observed in patients with late congenital syphilis.

Option D: Gottron's sign refers to erythematous macules and patches overlying the elbows and/or knees seen in dermatomyositis.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents with silvery-white scaly lesions on the extensor aspect of the elbows and knee. The clinical diagnosis is assisted by ______.
questions.solution:
The presence of silvery-white scaly lesions on the extensor aspect of the elbows and knee is a characteristic feature seen in psoriasis. The condition can be diagnosed clinically by demonstrating the Auspitz sign.

Auspitz sign is due to the elongated vessels in the dermal papilla which are under the thin supra papillary epidermis.

Demonstration of Auspitz Sign:
If superficial silvery scales are removed by scratching (grattage), then the scales come off attached together, as if one has scratched on a wax candle (wax candle scales).

Subsequently, a thin membrane, known as Bulkeley membrane is seen. Removal of Bulkeley membrane reveals classical pinpoint bleeding known as the Auspitz sign.

questions.text: An adolescent male presented with persistent, greasy, scaly and crusted papules over his neck, trunk, face, and scalp. His nail examination findings are given below. Based on these clinical features, identify the diagnosis.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of an adolescent male presenting with persistent, greasy, scaly and crusted papules over his seborrhoeic areas with a V-shaped nick at the nail's free edge is very suggestive of Darier's disease.

Darier's disease is an autosomal dominant condition that occurs due to dysfunction of the SERCA2 calcium channel due to ATP2A2 gene mutation, which is essential for desmosomal function. It results in acantholysis and dyskeratosis. 

They usually present as discrete or confluent rough, greasy, skin-colored, or yellowish-brown hyperkeratotic papules on the seborrhoeic areas of the trunk, face, scalp, ears, neck, and flexures. They are extensive, malodorous, and painful. Aggravating factors include friction, heat, sweating, and sunlight or UVB.

The following nail changes, also shown in the image below, are characteristic of Darier's disease:

  • Longitudinal erythronychia
  • Longitudinal leukonychia
  • Distal v-shaped nicks

Option A: Phrynoderma or toad skin manifests as groups of papules with a central keratotic plug. The commonest sites are elbows and knees. They are associated with vitamin A deficiency.

Option C: Seborrhoeic dermatitis is an inflammatory condition of the skin presenting with a papulosquamous morphology in areas rich in sebaceous glands, particularly the scalp, face, and body folds. Even though the clinical features overlaps with Darier's disease, the nail findings are absent in Seborrheic dermatitis.

Option D: Follicular eczema is a form of atopic dermatitis that presents with a discoid patch formed due to the coalescence of the follicular lesions with peripheral excoriation marks. The biopsy shows spongiotic dermatitis.

questions.text: A patient presented with a history of fever, myalgia, and severe arthralgia. She also developed pigmentation on the nose after a few days of the onset of these symptoms as shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given history of fever, myalgia, severe arthralgia, and nose hyperpigmentation (chik sign) points towards a diagnosis of chikungunya. 

Chik sign refers to a central facial pigmentation predominantly on the nose which develops during the acute phase of the disease. It helps in the retrospective diagnosis of Chikungunya infection. It most commonly affects the nose and cheeks. It appears as the fever subsides.

Chikungunya fever is due to infection with Chikungunya virus, spread by mosquitos and direct contact between humans. The Aedes aegypti and Aedes albopictus mosquitoes are the most common vectors.

It presents as an acute onset of fever, arthralgia, and myalgia with other flu symptoms such as headache, loss of appetite, and nausea. A maculopapular rash develops, which is more pronounced on the trunk. The rash may occasionally progress to petechiae and purpura. 

Diagnosis is mainly clinical, however, a definitive diagnosis can be made by the detection of IgM antibodies in the serum with ELISA or RTPCR.

Treatment is supportive with acetaminophen and NSAIDs. The rash can be managed with saline compresses and emollients. Persistent non-healing ulcers can be managed by topical or systemic antibiotics. Most of the skin lesions resolve within 2 weeks.

Other options:

Option A- Hyperpigmentation of the centrofacial face (nose and cheeks) mimics melasma and may be misdiagnosed if proper history is not taken. Melasma is hyperpigmented macules of the face that increase after sun exposure. 

The following image shows the hyperpigmentation of the face seen in melasma.

Option B- Melanocytic papillomatous nevi are acquired dermal nevi that are very common. They protrude from the skin surface and may be pigmented or skin-colored. Upon histological examination, they exhibit nevus cell nests in the dermis. Therapy consists of excision, shave excision, or laser therapy. 

Option C- Actinic keratosis is a pre-malignant lesion that consists of crusty, scaly patches of skin. It is associated with UV light exposure and is therefore associated with solar damage to the surrounding skin. 

The following image shows the scaly patches of skin suggestive of actinic keratosis of the scalp.

questions.text: In which of the following conditions is Nikolsky's sign positive?
questions.solution:
Nikolsky's sign is positive in the following conditions:

  • Pemphigus vulgaris
  • Pemphigus foliaceus
  • Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome

Nikolsky's sign refers to the separation of the normal‐looking epidermis from the dermis by applying firm tangential sliding pressure, thereby producing erosion. It is seen in conditions that produce intraepidermal blisters. Hence it is negative in subepidermal bullous conditions like bullous pemphigoid and epidermolysis bullosa acquisita.

Nikolsky sign is negative in:

  • Bullous pemphigoid
  • Erythema multiforme
  • Epidermolysis bullosa acquisita

Pseudo Nikolsky's sign is positive for Stevens-Johnson Syndrome, some burn cases, toxic epidermal necrolysis, and bullous ichthyosiform erythroderma. Here, the underlying pathophysiology is necrosis and not acantholysis, which is seen in the true Nikolsky's sign.

questions.text: Which among the following is the most common triggering factor for the skin lesion shown in the image below?

choices.text: Contact with irritants like poison ivy

questions.solution:
The given image shows characteristic target lesions of Erythema multiforme. It is most commonly associated with a preceding herpes simplex infection (facial or genital).

Target lesions, also known as bull's-eye lesions are a type of rash with a central clearing. They can appear on any part of the body, including the face, upper chest, back, arms, legs, hands, feet, and mucous membranes. They are a typical feature of erythema multiforme, a condition that often resolves in three to six weeks. Erythema multiforme lesions are annular, with a violaceous centre, pink halo, and pale ring. They are usually not painful but may cause a burning sensation. Target lesions are also a typical feature of Lyme disease, where they are known as erythema migrans.

Target lesions have three zones:

  • The central area of dusky erythema or purpura
  • Middle paler zone of edema, and
  • The outer ring of erythema with a well‐defined edge.

Atypical target lesions have only two of the three zones.

Erythema multiforme is a self‐limiting cytotoxic dermatitis that results from a cell‐mediated hypersensitivity reaction. It presents as a spectrum of macular, papular, or urticarial lesions, as well as the classic form -acral iris or target lesions. These lesions may involve the palms or trunk. The oral and genital mucosa can also be involved, and are associated with erosions.

The common triggers are

  • Herpes simplex infection (most common)
  • Mycoplasma infection
  • Bacterial infections
  • Fungal infections
  • Vaccinations
  • Malignancy: carcinoma, lymphoma, leukemia (Option B)
  • Drug reactions: sulfonamides, rifampicin, penicillins, hydantoin derivatives (Option C)
  • Miscellaneous: Lupus erythematosus (Rowell Syndrome), Sarcoidosis, Polyarteritis Nodosa

Topical agents like poison ivy can also trigger Erythema multiforme-like reactions but it is not the most common cause (Option A).

questions.text: Button-hole sign can be seen in which of the following disorders?
questions.solution:
Buttonhole sign is seen in type 1 neurofibromatosis (Von Recklinghausen's disease).

Neurofibromas can be invaginated into the subcutis with the tip of the index finger back and they reappear after the pressure is released. This is the buttonhole sign.

This sign is also positive in anetoderma and dermatofibroma.

questions.text: In a young boy who presented with molluscum contagiosum, it was noted that new lesions appeared at the site of scratching. What is this phenomenon called?
questions.solution:
The phenomenon where new lesions appeared at the site of scratching in a young boy presenting with molluscum contagiosum is pseudo-Koebner response.

Koebner/isomorphic response (Option B) refers to the appearance of new skin lesions in previously normal skin subjected to trauma. They are typically linear, as they follow the route of the injury.  It is more likely to occur when the disease is active.

Pseudo-Koebnerization refers to the appearance of similar skin lesions at the site of injury, resulting from the spread of an infective agent. It is seen in plane warts and molluscum contagiosum, 

Koebner phenomenon is seen in conditions like

  • Psoriasis
  • Vitiligo
  • Erythema multiforme
  • Lichen planus
  • Necrobiosis lipodica
  • Lupus erythematosus
  • Hailey-Hailey disease
  • Darier disease
  • Vasculitis
  • Pityriasis rubra pilaris

Other options: 

Option-C: Reverse Koebner phenomenon refers to the disappearance of skin lesions after trauma to the area, which is seen in psoriasis.

Option-D: Isotopic response is the emergence of a new lesion at the site of a previous unrelated dermatosis such as granuloma annulare developing at the site of herpes zoster and psoriasis developing at the site of contact dermatitis.

Related Pearl: Koebner phenomenon

Koebner or isomorphic Phenomenon is the development of new lesions along the line of trauma in a previously normal skin. The new lesions have 'iso' (same) and 'morphic' (morphology) as the existing lesions.

The trauma may include mechanical trauma, thermal trauma, allergic or irritant reactants or any treatment procedures.

Psoriasis

Lichen planus

Some rare causes of True Koebner Phenomenon are : Darier's disease, Hailey-Hailey disease, Erythema multiforme, Kaposi's Sarcoma and Lichen sclerosus.
